Brill's New Pauly: "Probus, M. Valerius, Latin philologist of the second half of the 1st cent. ... P. himself published only a few small works on questions of detail: 1. an explanation of abbreviations in public correspondence, De notis iuris (extant); 2. the Epistula ad Marcellum on prosody and on problems of grammatical detail; 3. De genetivo Graeco and 4. De temporum conexione (2.-4. lost)..... Late Antiquity and the Middle Ages considered P. one of the primary exponents of grammar ....ascribed to him grammatical treatises and commentaries (in part demonstrable secondary attributions); this increased his fame and inspired new attributions: 1. Instituta artium, an early 4th-cent. treatise on morphology by Palladius 2. a 5th-cent. conglomeration of grammatical excerpts transmitted as an annex to the Instituta ... the so-called Appendix Probi...3. Catholica, in reality the second book of a grammar by Plotius [II 5] Sacerdos....". Schmidt, Peter L. (Constance). “Probus”, in: Brill’s New Pauly, Antiquity volumes edited by: Hubert Cancik and , Helmuth Schneider. Consulted online on 06 September 2016
